audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	GB Airlines, this is Kyle speaking. How can I help?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: GB航空公司，我是凯尔。我能帮忙吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Hi, my name is Matt Walsh. I’m calling on behalf of Mr John Sparrow to claim expenses for a delay in his flight last week.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 嗨，我叫马特·沃尔什。我代表约翰·斯派洛先生打电话来，要求赔偿他上周航班延误的费用。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Good morning, Mr Walsh. Thank you for calling. Could you please tell me the flight number and the date of departure?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 早上好，沃尔什先生。谢谢你的来电。请告诉我航班号和起飞日期好吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	The date of departure was the 24th of January. 2016. I’m afraid I don’t have the flight number in front of me at the moment.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 出发日期是2016年1月24日。现在我恐怕不能提供航班号。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	OK, that’s all right. One moment, [typing] Could you tell me, where was Mr Sparrow departing from?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的，没关系。等一下，你能告诉我，斯派洛先生从哪里出发？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	He was departing from Athens.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 他从雅典出发。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Is that Athens, Greece or Athens, Georgia?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 那是希腊的雅典还是乔治亚州的雅典？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Athens. Greece.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 雅典。希腊。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Right. And what was the destination?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的。目的地是什么？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	It was Heathrow, London.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 那是伦敦希思罗机场。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Right. We’ve got two flights from Athens to London Heathrow on the 24th of January, 2016. Was it the 3:25 p.m. flight, or the 9:45 p.m.?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的。我们有两班2016年1月24日从雅典飞往伦敦希思罗机场的航班。是下午3点25分的班机，还是晚上9点45分的班机。？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	It was the later one, 9:45.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是后面那个，9点45分。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	OK, so the flight number is GB1011.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的，那么航班号是GB1011。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Right, OK.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，好的。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	OK, yes. I can see that Mr Sparrow’s flight was cancelled, and he was booked on the next flight on the 25th of January, at 3:25 p.m. Is that correct?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的，是的。我知道斯派洛先生的航班取消了，他订了1月25日下午3点25分的下一班航班，对吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Yes, that is correct.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，没错。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	According to our system, one of my colleagues spoke with Mr Sparrow on the phone on the 24th to inform him of the cancellation, and offered to book a hotel for him for the night, but Mr Sparrow preferred to book one himself.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 根据我们的系统，我的一位同事在24日与斯派洛先生通电话，告知他取消预订，并提出为他预订一家酒店过夜，但斯派洛先生更愿意自己预订一家酒店。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Yes, because he didn’t want to stay near the airport as the next flight was in the afternoon.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，因为下一班飞机是下午，他不想呆在机场附近。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE :	Yes, of course. Could you tell me which hotel he stayed at?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，当然。你能告诉我他住在哪家旅馆吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Yes. He stayed at the Hypnos Hotel.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 对。他住在海普诺斯酒店。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Could you spell that for me?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 你能帮我拼一下吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Of course. That’s H-Y-P-N-O-S.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 当然。那是H-Y-P-N-O-s。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Right, thank you for that. And could you please tell me how much the total cost was for the night?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的，谢谢你。你能告诉我今晚的总费用是多少吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Sure, it was 73 euros
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 当然，是73欧元

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Right. Do you have a copy of the receipt for that?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 正确的。你有收据复印件吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Yes, of course. Would you like me to send it to you?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，当然。你要我把它寄给你吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Yes, please.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，请。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Can I email a picture of it to you?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 我能把它的照片发电子邮件给你吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Absolutely. The email address is refunds@gbairlines.co.uk.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 当然。电子邮件地址是退款@gbairlines.co.uk。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Great, thank you.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 太好了，谢谢。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	No problem. Were there any other expenses you wish to claim?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 没问题。你还想报销其他费用吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Actually, yes. There was also the taxi ride to the airport, and the taxi ride back the next day.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 实际上，是的。还有去机场的出租车，还有第二天回来的出租车。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Right, and what was the total cost?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好吧，总费用是多少？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Uhm, the first taxi ride was 53 euros and the second one was 42, so... 63, 73, 83... Yeah, so the total was 95 euros. I’ll send you the receipt for those as well.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 嗯，第一次坐出租车是53欧元，第二次是42欧元，所以。。。63，73，83。。。是的，总共是95欧元。我也会把收据寄给你。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Thank you. Are there any other expenses?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 谢谢您。还有其他费用吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	No, I think that’s it.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 不，我想就这样。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Excellent. So, if you could please send us the receipts for the hotel and the taxi rides, and after we receive them it should take about 48 hours for the funds to reach Mr Sparrow’s account.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好极了。所以，如果您能把酒店和出租车的收据寄给我们，在我们收到收据后，大约需要48小时资金才能到达斯派洛先生的账户。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Perfect, thank you very much.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 太好了，非常感谢。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	My pleasure. Is there anything else I can help you with?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 我的荣幸。还有什么我能帮你的吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER	Actually, yes, there’s one more thing. Um, Mr Sparrow complained about the meal during the flight. He said that it was a bit...bland.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 实际上，是的，还有一件事。嗯，斯派洛先生抱怨航班上的饭菜。他说有点…清淡。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE	Right.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	So he asked me if it was possible to switch to a different meal option for his upcoming flight to Kiev next week.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 所以他问我是否有可能在下周飞往基辅的航班上换一种不同的餐食。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	Right, of course. Just give me a minute, please, [typing] Right,I see that Mr Sparrow had the light meal option for his flight to London, and you would like to change that. What would you like to change it to?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，当然。请给我一分钟，[打字]好的，我知道斯派洛先生在飞往伦敦的航班上有便餐选择，你想改变一下。你想把它改成什么？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	What are the other options?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 还有其他的选择吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE	We’ve got twelve different meal options. Would you like me to list all of them for you?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 我们有十二种不同的用餐选择。你要我把它们都列出来吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER	Well, Mr Sparrow has told me that he would prefer something without meat, so.. .how many of these do not contain meat?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 斯派洛先生告诉我他喜欢不带肉的东西，所以。其中有多少不含肉？

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE	We’ve got three meal options without meat: we’ve got the vegetarian option, the vegan option, and the Asian vegetarian.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 我们有三种不吃肉的选择：我们有素食者，素食者和亚洲素食者。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER	What’s the difference?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 有什么区别？

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE	There’s a variety of different dishes served with each option. For example, next week the vegetarian option will be a small spinach and feta cheese pie, a bread roll, a salad, and tropical fruit.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 每种选择都有各种不同的菜肴。例如，下周素食者可以选择一个小菠菜和菲塔奶酪派，一个面包卷，一份沙拉和热带水果。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER	And the vegan option?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 素食主义者的选择呢？

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	The vegan option doesn’t include any dairy products, and it also doesn’t include fowl, eggs, or honey. I’m afraid I don’t have the specific menu for this week, but I can email it to you as soon as it becomes available.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 纯素食品不包括任何乳制品，也不包括家禽、鸡蛋或蜂蜜。恐怕我没有这周的具体菜单，但一有空我就发电子邮件给你。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	Oh, could you do that? That would be great.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 哦，你能做到吗？那太好了。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE	Yes, of course. I can email you a detailed description of all the meal options, if you like.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，当然。如果你愿意的话，我可以给你发一封电子邮件，详细描述所有的用餐选择。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER	Yes, please.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，请。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE:	No problem. Please do not forget to call us back to change the meal option. You need to do that 48 hours before the departure time for international flights, and 24 hours for domestic flights.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 没问题。请别忘了给我们回电话，让我们改变用餐方式。国际航班起飞前48小时，国内航班24小时前。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER:	So, 48 hours for this one, then?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 那么，这个48小时？

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE：	Yes, exactly.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，没错。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER：	Perfect.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 很完美。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE：	No, I’m sorry. Um, transatlantic flights require 48 hours. All flights within Europe require 24 hours, so in this case you will need to call us 24 hours in advance. I apologise for that.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 不，对不起。嗯，跨大西洋飞行需要48小时。所有在欧洲的航班都需要24小时，所以在这种情况下，您需要提前24小时给我们打电话。我为此道歉。

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER：	OK, great.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好吧，太好了。

audio_lrc.dialog: EMPLOYEE：	So, could I please have your email address so I can send you the menus?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 那么，请告诉我你的电子邮件地址，好把菜单发给你吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: CUSTOMER：	Certainly. It’s matt.walsh@sparrowltd.com...
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 当然。它是马特·沃尔什@sparrowltd.com...

groups.description:
Complete the notes.
Write **NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS AND /OR A NUMBER** in each gap.
groups.content:
#### EXPENSES CLAIM INFORMATION - GB AIRLINES
Customer name: Mr [i[=NO=]]
Date of Departure：[i[=NO=]] 2016
Flight Number： GB1011
Flight: From [i[=NO=]]to London Heathrow, UK
Departure Time： [i[=NO=]]p.m.
Expenses Claimed:[i[=NO=]] Hotel, 73 euros
Taxis, [i[=NO=]]

questions.analysis: I’m calling on behalf of Mr John Sparrow to claim expenses for a delay in his flight last week.
The date of departure was the 24th of January. 2016.
Athens. Greece.
It was the later one, 9:45.
He stayed at the Hypnos Hotel.
Uhm, the first taxi ride was 53 euros and the second one was 42, so... 63, 73, 83... Yeah, so the total was 95 euros. I’ll send you the receipt for those as well.

groups.description:
Complete the sentences.
Write **NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS AND /OR A NUMBER** in each gap.
groups.content:
- The customer had the option  [i[=NO=]]for his previous flight.
- There are three meal options without meat: vegetarian, vegan, and [i[=NO=]]
- The vegan option doesn’t contain any [i[=NO=]] ,eggs, fowl, or honey.
- The meal option for the customer’s flight to Kiev must be changed [i[=NO=]] before the departure time.

questions.analysis: Right, of course. Just give me a minute, please, [typing] Right,I see that Mr Sparrow had the light meal option for his flight to London, and you would like to change that. What would you like to change it to?
We’ve got three meal options without meat: we’ve got the vegetarian option, the vegan option, and the Asian vegetarian.
The vegan option doesn’t include any dairy products, and it also doesn’t include fowl, eggs, or honey.
No, I’m sorry. Um, transatlantic flights require 48 hours. All flights within Europe require 24 hours, so in this case you will need to call us 24 hours in advance.

audio_lrc.dialog: Hello, and welcome to the home page for the Healthy Hearing Medical Clinic and Surgery, where we’d like to share a little more information about the services we provide and more.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 您好，欢迎来到健康听力医疗诊所和外科的主页，我们想在这里分享我们提供的服务的更多信息。

audio_lrc.dialog: Our hospital is one of the leading specialised hospitals in the United Kingdom, attracting the very best healthcare professionals from around the globe. Not only are we a leading medical practice, but we are also the only hospital in the United Kingdom dedicated entirely to the treatment of, and research into the curing of hearing loss. Our facilities and staff here are renowned across Europe, attracting thousands of patients a year. Our consultations can number anything up to 11,000 patients a year, however we aim to treat around 5,000 patients a year so as to maintain and ensure the quality of our services. Our patients are guaranteed the highest standard of care, as well as the use of our first class facilities. All patients requiring overnight treatment are provided with their own private room with en-suite facilities, as well as a state-of-the-art entertainment centre, which includes a flat screen LCD television and Playstation.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 我们的医院是英国领先的专科医院之一，吸引了全球最优秀的医疗保健专业人士。我们不仅是一家领先的医疗机构，而且我们也是英国唯一一家完全致力于听力损失治疗和研究的医院。我们在这里的设施和员工在欧洲享有盛誉，每年吸引数千名患者。我们每年的会诊人数可达11000人，但我们的目标是每年治疗约5000名病人，以维持和确保我们的服务质量。我们保证为患者提供最高标准的护理，并使用我们一流的设施。所有需要整夜治疗的患者都有自己的私人房间和套房设施，以及最先进的娱乐中心，其中包括一台平板液晶电视和游戏机。

audio_lrc.dialog: Appointments with our healthcare professionals can be made at any time during the week, with female doctors available between 8 am and 11 am. If you need to see a doctor outside of these times, please visit the ‘Out of Hours’ page of our website for more information. Our doctors are all trained to an exceptionally high standard, and practice a vast array of specialties: Mr. Robert is a fully qualified ear and throat specialist, Mr. Edwards is a pediatric hearing specialist, while Mr. Green specialises in reversing hearing loss. For more details about our people, please visit the ‘Staff Members’ page on our website.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 我们的专业医护人员可以在一周内的任何时间预约，女医生可以在上午8点到11点之间提供服务。如果您需要在这些时间之外去看医生，请访问我们网站的“下班时间”页面了解更多信息。我们的医生都受过非常高的标准训练，并且实践了大量的专业：罗伯特先生是一位完全合格的耳喉专家，爱德华兹先生是儿科听力专家，而格林专门从事逆转听力损失。有关我们员工的更多详细信息，请访问我们网站上的“员工”页面。

audio_lrc.dialog: During a consultation, doctors will sometimes decide medication is required, for which patients should receive a prescription. There are several pharmacies within the city; however we recommend that patients use the pharmacy housed within our health care facility.Our in-house pharmacy is well-stocked at all times, our products are competitively priced, and our pharmacists are on hand to help and advise from 8 am until 10 pm from Monday to Saturday, and from 9 am until 12 pm on Sundays. If you require any help outside of these hours, please see our ‘Out of Hours’ page on the website.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 在会诊过程中，医生有时会决定是否需要药物治疗，而病人应该得到处方。本市有几家药房，但我们建议患者使用本医疗机构内的药房设施。我们的内部药房的库存一直很充足，我们的产品价格极具竞争力，我们的药剂师从周一到周六上午8点到晚上10点，以及从上午9点到12点随时提供帮助和建议周日下午。如果您在工作时间以外需要任何帮助，请访问我们网站上的“下班时间”页面。

audio_lrc.dialog: Since the Healthy Hearing Medical Clinic and Surgery also functions as a teaching hospital, we aim to provide our students with every opportunity to expose themselves to medicine in practice. Therefore we would like to encourage our patients to give their consent for a medical student to attend their consultations. If our patients are not comfortable with this, there will be a form at reception where patients will be able to opt out.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 由于健康听力医疗诊所和外科也起到教学医院的作用，我们的目标是为学生提供在实践中接触医学的一切机会。因此，我们鼓励患者同意医学生参加他们的会诊。如果我们的病人对此不满意，接待处会有一张表格，病人可以选择退出。

audio_lrc.dialog: Now, please look at the map I’ve given you of the Healthy Hearing Medical Clinic and Surgery. For those not familiar with our practice, reception can be found through the main door at the end of the corridor. If your consultation is booked with Mr. Green, you need to go through the main door and turn right by the nurses’ desk, and his office is at the end of the corridor on your left-hand side. If you need to alter any of your personal details, please visit our secretary at the Office for Medical Records, which you will find next to the therapy room. If you’re awaiting surgery, please first check in with reception, before taking the first door on the right after you enter the clinic. Finally, in the event that you feel disappointed with any of the services we have provided, or have any further questions, please locate our Manager’s Office, which can be found near the Office for Medical Records and between two closets.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 现在，请看我给你的健康听力医疗诊所和手术的地图。对于不熟悉我们的做法的人，可以通过走廊尽头的正门找到接待处。如果你与格林先生订了会诊，你需要经过主门，然后由护士台右转，他的办公室就在走廊左边的尽头。如果您需要更改您的任何个人信息，请访问我们办公室的秘书以获取病历，您可以在治疗室旁边找到。如果您正在等待手术，请先到接待处办理入住手续，然后在您进入诊所后右侧的第一个门前办理手续。最后，如果您对我们提供的任何服务感到失望，或有任何进一步的问题，请找到我们的经理办公室，该办公室位于办公室附近和两个衣柜之间。

audio_lrc.dialog: If you have any more questions about the Healthy Hearing Medical Clinic and Surgery, please do not hesitate to contact us on 01256 111 111. [fade out]
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 如果您对健康听力医疗诊所和手术有任何疑问，请随时拨打01256-111-111与我们联系。

questions.analysis: Our consultations can number anything up to 11,000 patients a year, however we aim to treat around 5,000 patients a year so as to maintain and ensure the quality of our services
questions.content: How many patients does the hospital consult every year?

questions.analysis: Appointments with our healthcare professionals can be made at any time during the week, with female doctors available between 8 am and 11 am.
questions.content: When can patients meet the female doctor?

questions.analysis: while Mr. Green specialises in reversing hearing loss.
questions.content: Who is the expert on treating hearing loss?

questions.analysis: however we recommend that patients use the pharmacy housed within our health care facility
questions.content: Where are patients recommended to buy their medicine?

questions.analysis: Therefore we would like to encourage our patients to give their consent for a medical student to attend their consultations.
questions.content: What will the patients be asked about whether they are willing to do?

options.text: Letting one student attend the consultation
Asking postgraduate students to do treatment

questions.analysis: reception can be found through the main door at the end of the corridor.
his office is at the end of the corridor on your left-hand side
which you will find next to the therapy room
If you’re awaiting surgery, please first check in with reception, before taking the first door on the right after you enter the clinic.
please locate our Manager’s Office, which can be found near the Office for Medical Records and between two closets.

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Right Julia, so from your CV and portfolio, and what you’ve already told me, you seem to be very much the sort of person we’re looking for on the postgraduate course.So tell me, you finished your Fashion Design course in London four years ago - did you think of carrying straight on and doing a higher degree at the time?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好吧，茱莉亚，从你的简历和作品集，以及你已经告诉我的信息来看，你似乎正是我们正在寻找的研究生人选当然。所以告诉我，你四年前在伦敦完成了你的时装设计课程——你当时有没有想过继续深造，攻读更高的学位？

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Yes - but there were financial pressures. So I ended up working in the retail industry, as you can see from my CV. And actually it was a very useful experience.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，但是有经济压力。所以我最终选择在零售业工作，你可以从我的简历中看到。实际上这是一次非常有用的经历。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Mmm. In what way?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 嗯。以什么方式？

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Well, I was lucky to get the job with Fashion Now- they're a big store, and, one of my priorities was to get as much experience as possible in different areas, so that was good because I had the chance to work in lots of different departments. And having direct contact with the customers meant I was able to see how they reacted to innovation---- to new fashion ideas, because with Fashion Now, a designer might show something in New York or Milan and there’ll be something similar in the shop within weeks. So,that was probably the most useful thing for me.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 嗯，我很幸运现在能在时尚界得到这份工作——他们是一家大商店，而且，我的首要任务之一就是在不同领域获得尽可能多的经验，这很好，因为我有机会在许多不同的部门工作。与顾客直接接触意味着我可以看到他们对创新的反应——对新的时尚理念的反应，因为现在的时尚，设计师可能会在纽约或米兰展示一些东西，几周内商店里也会有类似的东西。所以，这对我来说可能是最有用的。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Right. And so what's made you decide to do a postgraduate course now?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的。那是什么让你决定现在读研究生课程？

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Erm ... Well, while I enjoyed working at Fashion Now, and I learned a lot there, I felt... well, the way forward would have been to develop my managerial skills rather than my skills in fashion design, and I’m not sure that’s what I want to do.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 呃...嗯，虽然我现在很喜欢在时尚界工作，在那里我学到了很多东西，但我觉得...好吧，未来的道路应该是发展我的管理技能，而不是我在时装设计方面的技能，我不确定这是我想做的。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Mmm, yes.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 嗯，是的。

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	When I was doing my degree in London I’d been interested in women’s wear. But I know that there’s been a lot of work done in areas like new fabric construction - and, though I’m not intending to go too deeply into the technology - I'd be very interested in looking at how new fabrics could be used in children’s wear, so I'd like the chance to pursue that line.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 当我在伦敦攻读学位时，我对女装很感兴趣。但我知道在新面料构造等领域已经做了很多工作，而且，虽然我不打算对这项技术做太深入的研究，但我对如何将新面料应用于童装非常感兴趣，所以我希望有机会从事这项工作。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Yes. Good. And are you at all concerned about what it’s going to be like coming back into an academic context after being away from it for several years?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 对。很好。你是否真的担心在离开了几年之后回到学术环境中会是什么样子？

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	No, I'm looking forward to it. But I’m basically more interested in the application than the theory - or at least that's what I've found so far, and I'm hoping the course will give me the contacts and skills I need eventually to set up my own enterprise. I’m particularly interested by the overseas links that the department has.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 不，我很期待。但我基本上对这个应用程序比对理论更感兴趣——或者至少这是我目前所发现的，我希望这门课程能给我建立自己企业所需的人脉和技能。我对这一部门的海外联系特别感兴趣。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Yes, many of our students look overseas or to international companies for sponsorship of their projects.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，我们的许多学生都希望海外或国际公司赞助他们的项目。

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	And the facilities here look excellent. I just went to look at the library - it’s really impressive. There’s so much room compared with the one at my old university.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 这里的设施看起来很好。我只是去看了一下图书馆，真是令人印象深刻。和我以前的大学相比，空间太大了。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Yes, most students find it's a good place to study. And there are linkups to other universities, of course, and all the usual electronic sources - the staff run an Information Skills Programme which we recommend all postgraduates do in the first week or two. Design students find the Special Collections particularly useful.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，大多数学生都觉得这是个学习的好地方。当然，还有与其他大学的联系，以及所有常见的电子资源——教职员工开办一个信息技能课程，我们建议所有研究生在第一、两周内完成。设计专业的学生发现这些特别的收藏品特别有用。

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Yes.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 对。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Then we have a separate Computer Centre, which has its own academic coordinator, Tim Spender-he's got a background in art design, and the ethos of the centre is that it’s a studio for innovation and creativity, rather than a computer laboratory.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 然后我们有一个独立的计算机中心，它有自己的学术协调人，蒂姆·斯宾德他有艺术设计的背景，这个中心的精神是它是一个创新和创造力的工作室，而不是一个计算机实验室。

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Oh, right. I liked the study spaces where students can sit and discuss work together - very useful for joint projects. We always had to do that sort of thing in the cafeteria when I was an undergraduate. And I read in the brochure that there’s a separate resource for photography.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 哦，对。我喜欢学生们可以坐在一起讨论工作的学习空间，这对联合项目非常有用。当我还是大学生的时候，我们总是要在自助餐厅里做那种事。我在小册子上读到有一个单独的摄影资源。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Yes, it's called Photomedia. It's not just for photography but things like digital imaging and new media. It's a resource for all our students, not just fashion design, and we encourage students to work there producing work that crosses disciplinary boundaries. It’s well used - in fact, it’s doubled in size since it was set up three years ago. And we also have an offshoot from that which is called Time Based Media - this is for students---who want to develop their ideas in the area of the moving image or sound. That's in a new building that was specially built for it just last year, but there are plans to expand it as the present facilities are overstretched already.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 是的，它叫光媒体。它不仅适用于摄影，还适用于数字成像和新媒体。这是我们所有学生的资源，不仅仅是时装设计，我们鼓励学生在那里工作，创作出跨越学科界限的作品。它使用得很好——事实上，自从三年前成立以来，它的规模已经翻了一番。我们还有一个分支叫做基于时间的媒体-这是为学生-谁想发展他们的想法在运动图像或声音领域。这是在去年专门为它建造的一座新大楼里，但由于目前的设施已经捉襟见肘，有计划对其进行扩建。

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Right.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好的。

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Now, is there anything you’d like to ask about the course itself?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 现在，关于课程本身，你有什么想问的吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Erm, ... I know it’s a combination of taught modules and a specialist project, but how does assessment fit in?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 呃。。。我知道这是一个教学模块和一个专业项目的结合，但评估是如何适应的呢？

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	Well, as you’d expect on a course of this nature, it’s an ongoing process. The degree course has four stages, and there are what we call progress reviews at the end of each of the first three. Then the final assessment is based on your project. You have to produce a report which is a critical reflection on your work.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 好吧，正如你所期望的那样，这是一个持续的过程。学位课程有四个阶段，在前三个阶段的每一个结束时都有我们称之为进度回顾的阶段。最后的评估是基于你的项目。你必须写一份对你的工作进行批判性反思的报告。

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	And is there some sort of fashion show?
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 有什么时装秀吗？

audio_lrc.dialog: Dr Hilsden:	There’s an exhibition. The projects aren’t all focused on clothes as such, some are more experimental, so that seems more appropriate. We ask representatives of fashion companies along, and it’s usually well attended.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 有个展览。这些项目并不是所有的重点都放在衣服上，有些更具实验性，所以这看起来更合适。我们邀请时装公司的代表一起参加，通常出席人数很多。

audio_lrc.dialog: Julia:	Right. And another thing I wanted to ask ...
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 没问题。另外我还有一件事想问……

questions.analysis: And having direct contact with the customers meant I was able to see how they reacted to innovation---- to new fashion ideas,
questions.content: What is the main thing Julia feels she has gained from her experience in retail?

options.text: improved ability to predict fashion trends
more skill in setting priorities in her work

questions.analysis: I'd be very interested in looking at how new fabrics could be used in children’s wear,
questions.content: Why is Julia interested in doing the postgraduate course?

options.text: It will enable her to develop new types of technology.
It will allow her to specialise in a design area of her choice.
It will provide managerial training focusing on her needs.

questions.analysis: I need eventually to set up my own enterprise.
questions.content: What would Julia like to do after she has completed the postgraduate course?

groups.description:
What does each university facility have?
Choose the correct answer and move it into the gap.

questions.analysis: the staff run an Information Skills Programme which we recommend all postgraduates do in the first week or two.

Then we have a separate Computer Centre, which has its own academic coordinator, Tim Spender-he's got a background in art design, and the ethos of the centre is that it’s a studio for innovation and creativity, rather than a computer laboratory.
we encourage students to work there producing work that crosses disciplinary boundaries
That's in a new building that was specially built for it just last year

groups.description: Write **NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS ** in each gap.
groups.content:
#### MA in Fashion Design: Assessment
Assessment includes three  [i[=NO=]] which take place at the end of the stages of the degree. Final assessment is based on a project, and includes the student’s  [i[=NO=]], in the form of a written report, and the  [i[=NO=]], to which representatives of fashion companies are invited.

questions.analysis: The degree course has four stages, and there are what we call progress reviews at the end of each of the first three.
You have to produce a report which is a critical reflection on your work.
There’s an exhibition.

audio_lrc.dialog: Today, we’re going to consider the results of a recent experiment into the behaviour of wild mice. Now, if you’ve ever kept a mouse, or a hamster or guinea pig, as a pet, you probably kept it in a cage with a water bottle, a food dish and an exercise wheel. Small pets like mice will spend a lot of time running inside the exercise wheel, making it spin round and round. And if you’ve ever seen a pet mouse running in an exercise wheel, you’ve no doubt seen them smiling and really going for it - you can’t help getting the idea that mice enjoy running in exercise wheels.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 今天，我们将讨论最近一项针对野生老鼠行为的实验结果。现在，如果你曾经养过一只老鼠，或者一只仓鼠或者豚鼠作为宠物，你可能会把它放在一个笼子里，里面有一个水瓶，一个食物盘和一个运动轮。像老鼠这样的小宠物会花很多时间在运动轮里跑，使它转来转去。如果你曾经看到过一只宠物老鼠在运动轮上奔跑，你一定会看到它们微笑着，并且真的很努力——你会不由得产生这样的想法：老鼠喜欢在运动轮上跑步。

audio_lrc.dialog: But is this actually the case, and what can science tell us? Traditionally, there were two explanations for why mice in captivity - whether kept as pets, or for research - would run in exercise wheels. First, there’s the possibility that the mice are running to relieve the stress of being confined. This means that there is a psychological benefit, or reward, from running in the exercise wheel. The other explanation is that running in the exercise wheel is a stereotyped behaviour - an activity that is repetitive, that is repeated in the same way countless times, without ever achieving any goal.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 但事实是这样吗？科学能告诉我们什么？传统上，对于圈养的老鼠——无论是作为宠物饲养，还是用于研究——都有两种解释，那就是为什么老鼠会在运动轮上奔跑。首先，有一种可能是老鼠跑来缓解被束缚的压力。这意味着，在锻炼中跑步有一种心理上的好处，或者说是奖励。另一种解释是，在练习盘上跑步是一种刻板的行为——一种重复性的活动，以同样的方式重复无数次，却从未达到任何目标。

audio_lrc.dialog: Until recently, the common view among scientists was that all this running in exercise wheels by mice in cages was a stereotyped behaviour. To understand the prevalence of this view, let’s consider the three main criteria that define a stereotyped behaviour: the behaviour is observed only in animals in cages, not in the wild; second, the behaviour is repetitive, invariably the same, with no apparent purpose or benefit; and finally, the behaviour does not depend on external stimuli, such as a reward, or is only partially dependent on such stimuli.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 直到最近，科学家们的普遍看法是，笼子里的老鼠在运动轮上奔跑是一种刻板的行为。为了理解这种观点的普遍性，让我们考虑定义刻板行为的三个主要标准：这种行为只在笼子里的动物身上观察到，而不是在野外观察到的；第二，这种行为是重复的，总是相同的，没有明显的目的或好处；最后，这种行为不依赖于外部刺激，比如奖励，或者只是部分依赖于这样的刺激。

audio_lrc.dialog: The traditional understanding, then, is that captive mice run on exercise wheels even when there is no external stimulus because it’s a stereotyped behaviour. This would be similar to when people are confined to a small room, or prisoners to a cell, and they will pace back and forth for no reason - that pacing is also a stereotyped behaviour. However, this understanding depends on the idea that the mice are running in the wheels because they are confined, and that they wouldn’t run in the wheels in other circumstances.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 传统的理解是，即使在没有外部刺激的情况下，圈养的老鼠也会在运动轮上奔跑，因为这是一种刻板的行为。这就好比人们被关在一个小房间里，或者囚徒关在牢房里，他们会无缘无故地来回踱步——这种踱步也是一种刻板的行为。然而，这种理解依赖于这样一种观点：老鼠是在轮子里跑的，因为它们是被限制的，在其他情况下它们不会在轮子里跑。

audio_lrc.dialog: A team of Dutch scientists set out to investigate whether this was actually the case, by setting up exercise wheels outside. They placed exercise wheels in small boxes - so that larger animals could not interfere - and the boxes were placed in two areas that were populated by wild mice and other small animals: an urban area - one of the professor’s back gardens - and a rural area, a remote dune that could not be accessed by the public. Cameras recorded all visits to the exercise wheels over a period of three years. Most importantly, there was food in the box, but the animals could eat the food whether or not they chose to run in the exercise wheel.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 一个由荷兰科学家组成的研究小组通过在室外安装锻炼轮来调查是否真的是这样。他们把运动轮放在小盒子里，这样大的动物就不会干扰它们了，盒子被放在两个有野生老鼠和其他小动物居住的地方：一个是城市，一个是教授的后花园，另一个是一个偏远的沙丘，公众无法进入。摄像机记录了三年来对健身车的所有访问。最重要的是，盒子里有食物，但是动物们可以吃这些食物，不管它们是否选择在运动轮上跑步。

audio_lrc.dialog: In the course of the experiment, the running wheels were used more than 12.000 times, by animals including mice, frogs, slugs and birds. Mice, however, accounted for 88% of the wheel running. For the final months of the experiment, the researchers removed food from the boxes, leading to a drop in the frequency of visits to the boxes. Even so, visits where the wheel was used increased by 42%. This suggests that mice visited the boxes solely to run on the exercise wheel. As a result, the scientists concluded that running in an exercise wheel is inherently rewarding to wild mice.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 在实验过程中，包括老鼠、青蛙、鼻涕虫和鸟类在内的动物使用了超过12000次的轮子。然而，老鼠占了88%的车轮转动。在实验的最后几个月里，研究人员把食物从盒子里拿出来，导致人们去看盒子的频率下降。即便如此，使用方向盘的访问量也增加了42%。这表明老鼠造访盒子仅仅是为了在运动轮上奔跑。因此，科学家们得出结论，在运动轮上跑步对野生老鼠来说是一种奖励。

audio_lrc.dialog: This research has proven that wheel running is not a stereotyped behaviour, as it was observed in wild mice. Effectively, this means that we are left with the first theory of why mice run in wheels - there is a fundamental benefit or goal to the activity, that is, the activity is psychologically rewarding. What’s the reward to mice in running in a wheel? The answer is simple: they run because they enjoy it.
audio_lrc.paraphrase: 这项研究已经证明，车轮跑动并不像在野生老鼠身上观察到的那样是一种刻板的行为。实际上，这意味着我们只剩下关于老鼠为什么会在轮子里跑的第一个理论——活动有一个基本的好处或目标，也就是说，活动在心理上是有回报的。老鼠在轮子里跑有什么奖励？答案很简单：他们跑步是因为他们喜欢跑步。

groups.description:
Complete the notes.
Write **NO MORE THAN  ONE WORD AND/OR A NUMBER** in each gap.
groups.content:
**WILD MICE AND EXERCISE WHEELS**
Two traditional theories as to why mice run inside exercise wheels： - To relieve [i[=NO=]]：the activity has a psychological benefit. - It’s a stereotyped behaviour：a repetitive activity without a [i[=NO=]]
Three criteria for a stereotyped behaviour： - The behaviour occurs only in animals in [i[=NO=]], not in animals in nature. - The behaviour is recurring and always the same, with no clear purpose. - There is no external stimulus for the behaviour; for example, there is no [i[=NO=]]. Traditionally, wheel running by captive mice has been understood as a stereotyped behaviour. - This is because they do it even in the absence of a stimulus. This is similar to [i[=NO=]]in a cell pacing back and forth for no reason.
Two locations for the experiment involving wild mice： - An [i[=NO=]]area (a professor’s back garden) - A rural area (a remote dune inaccessible to the public)
Results of the experiment： - The running wheels were used more than [i[=NO=]]times. - Later on, researches removed food from the boxes, yet the visits where the wheel - was used increased by [i[=NO=]]. - Scientists concluded that running in an exercise wheel is inherently [i[=NO=]]to wild mice. - This means that the first theory is effectively true: mice run in wheels because it is something that they [i[=NO=]].

questions.analysis: First, there’s the possibility that the mice are running to relieve the stress of being confined.
that is repeated in the same way countless times, without ever achieving any goal.
the behaviour is observed only in animals in cages, not in the wild
the behaviour does not depend on external stimuli, such as a reward, or is only partially dependent on such stimuli.
his would be similar to when people are confined to a small room, or prisoners to a cell,
the boxes were placed in two areas that were populated by wild mice and other small animals: an urban area
In the course of the experiment, the running wheels were used more than 12.000 times,
Even so, visits where the wheel was used increased by 42%.
As a result, the scientists concluded that running in an exercise wheel is inherently rewarding to wild mice.
The answer is simple: they run because they enjoy it.
